channel.title: C# On Linux Help
channel.description:
Hey guys. So I've been getting tired of Windows and decided to download Fedora and Ubuntu. Saw that I liked the features of Fedora, but Ubuntu was cleaner so I installed it on a small 6GB partition of my hard drive.
I've been thinking about wiping the rest of my drive and installing Linux as my Primary Operating System. But I'm making sure I can use everything on Linux(Because I need to develop C# Applications for School). So here is my problem.
So far the only thing I have downloaded for C# development is MonoDevelop.(I realize I can use Visual Studio through WINE, haven't tried yet.) And I've opened a few of my projects from my flash drive to test out MonoDevelop. Everything works as I intended to apart from searching the C:\ for file names. But I can't seem to find out how to use the Visual Designer. Is there even one? My applications are Windows Forms Apps, so being able to make changes and add controls are essential. Is this possible? I've done very little research on this subject, but have tried a few things and failed.
Linux users, is my only option out of this using Visual Studio with Wine?

item.title: C# On Linux Help
item.dc:creator: @austinsobes austinsobes
item.description:
@austinsobes wrote:

[quote=“ziplock, post:13, topic:435926”][quote author=t4 link=topic=538645.msg3944937#msg3944937 date=1331769538]

I also find it a bit odd to be developing Windows Forms apps on Linux, seeing as you can’t see what it would actually. That’s why mono ships with GTK# when installing on Windows.

And no one wants to download all of that for some indie application.

???
[/quote]

Mono, GTK#, shitty hipster auto-typer or whatever he’s going to write.[/quote]

Wannabe programmer alert. It’s a shame you act so big when you can’t even read. I CLEARLY stated that I needed this for SCHOOL purposes. The language I used for out-of-school programming is C++ and Java.

Read full topic

[/quote]
sry i enjoy straight forward permissions, POSIX compliance, and powerful shells that work right out of the box[/quote]AND ITS ALL FREE!!!11111111111111111

item.title: C# On Linux Help
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“ziplock, post:9, topic:435926”][quote author=_s link=topic=538645.msg3944564#msg3944564 date=1331743921]

… Why?!?
[/quote]why what? why c#? because people like it.

Well there is obviously different languages for different situations, and nig-rigging C# for developing in Linux is kind of ridiculous. C# is great for rapid development of applications and games in Windows. I just don’t think it’s worth it when everyone has to install Mono to use a shitty auto-typer in Linux, when another language would make it much more convenient for the users and developers. Also in my experience, Mono is pretty shitty for anything besides command line applications.[/quote]it’s no worse than everyone having to install the jre or .net framework. in fact, most modern programming languages require a big fat runtime or interpreter.

[quote=“ziplock, post:13, topic:435926”][quote author=t4 link=topic=538645.msg3944937#msg3944937 date=1331769538]

I also find it a bit odd to be developing Windows Forms apps on Linux, seeing as you can’t see what it would actually. That’s why mono ships with GTK# when installing on Windows.

And no one wants to download all of that for some indie application.

???
[/quote]

Mono, GTK#, shitty hipster auto-typer or whatever he’s going to write.[/quote]hipster? haha, stfu

Read full topic

item.title: C# On Linux Help
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

GTK# is pretty common in cross-platform open source applications

Read full topic

item.title: C# On Linux Help
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

t4:

mono and GTK# are pretty common libraries…

For a windows machine I wouldn’t think so. I’ve yet to install Mono on my machine, though. I’m not exactly sure how popular it is, I’ve just never had a situation arise where I’ve needed it. I run any .net application in WINE pretty well.

Read full topic

item.title: C# On Linux Help
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

t4:

i don’t use C# so can’t give you a native solution, however i can recommend using a virtual machine (VMWare Player or Virtual Box) if all else fails.

This is actually a good point. You can install a copy of Windows under a virtual machine and run it in Unity mode with linux. Although not a great solution, its better than trying to get it all compatible with Wine.

Read full topic

item.description:

I don’t think MonoDevelop has a visual GUI builder at all. I admit I only played with it for a little, but I never found one.

Read full topic
